pages.text: I am about to leave my office and I have been meaning to get some exercise, so I think I will walk home today. I exit the building and walk along the sidewalk in the direction of my home. This is unfamiliar for me as I haven't walked home in years.$(br2)The stunning high-rises in downtown, where I work, are quickly replaced with dilapidated three-story

apartment buildings as I walk. I begin to feel unsafe and I check my pockets to make sure everything is in place.$(br2)As I walk further, the apartments are replaced with a large field with hundreds of tents and scores of homeless people clustering around them. I feel sympathy for these people, but not empathy as I cannot fully understand how they feel. Our experiences are so vastly different that it's unproductive for me to try to understand. It's better to

ignore them and walk faster.$(br2)The environment quickly returns to the opulence I am used to, and I breathe a sigh of relief. I reach the gate to my home, my butler opens it for me and escorts me to my mansion. I walk inside and collapse on the couch. This walk was hard work and made me uncomfortable. I don't think I will do this again any time soon.
